description: The scroll() and scrollBy() methods change the scroll position of overflow content within an element. Similar to setting scrollTop and scrollLeft properties, but with options setting whether the scroll should animate smoothly or jump. Note that scrollTo() is an alias for scroll().
description_html: The scroll() and scrollBy() methods change the scroll position of overflow content within an element. Similar to setting scrollTop and scrollLeft properties, but with options setting whether the scroll should animate smoothly or jump. Note that scrollTo() is an alias for scroll().
name: Scroll methods on elements

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 21, when an element's content does not generate a vertical scrollbar, then its scrollHeight property is equal to its clientHeight property. This can mean either the content is too short to require a scrollbar or that the element has a CSS style overflow value of visible (non-scrollable).

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 21, when an element's content does not generate a vertical scrollbar, then its scrollHeight property is equal to its clientHeight property. This can mean either the content is too short to require a scrollbar or that the element has a CSS style overflow value of visible (non-scrollable).

ie.notes: In Internet Explorer 5 through 7, if padding is set, the value of scrollHeight is equal to the sum of the top and bottom padding. This behavior was fixed in Internet Explorer 8.

chrome.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 41319147.

chrome_android.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 41319147.

edge.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 41319147.

ie.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 100-0 (most left to most right) instead of negative values.

oculus.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 41319147.

samsunginternet_android.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 41319147.

webview_android.notes: For right-to-left elements, this property uses 0-100 (most left to most right) instead of negative values. See bug 41319147.

ie.notes: In Internet Explorer 5 through 7, if padding is set, the value of scrollWidth is equal to the sum of the left and right padding. This behavior was fixed in Internet Explorer 8.

safari.notes: Safari does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

safari_ios.notes: Safari on iOS does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

webview_ios.notes: WebView on iOS does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

safari.notes: Safari does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

safari_ios.notes: Safari on iOS does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

webview_ios.notes: WebView on iOS does not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

safari.notes: Before version 15.4, Safari did not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

safari_ios.notes: Before version 15.4, Safari on iOS did not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.

webview_ios.notes: Before version 15.4, WebView on iOS did not have support for the smooth scroll behavior.
